sentence2: 13 . and 17 . and in respect of his conditions and qualities , that he should be for opposition an adversary , although a disguised enemy ; for pride and ambition , advancing himselfe above all that is called god : for his other vices , a man of sinne in generall , and more specially an horrible idolatour : in regard of his effects , that he and his followers should be workers of signes and wonders , in the sight of men , that he should compell all sorts of men to receive the marke or name of the beast , or number of his name : and lastly , for that which he was to suster , that christ shall consume him with the breath of his mouth , that is , the ministery of the gospell ; and that thereupon the ten hornes which first assisted him , shall afterwards assault him : it followeth therefore , that unto such as we affirme to be antichrist , all these notes are to be applied , ( as we have applied them all to the pope of rome ) whereas contrariwise the deniall of any one essentiall property , is an argument sufficient to proove the negative .

sentence1: there are in the papisticall bisshops ( if i be not begiled ) farre better fasyons and vertves , wherof leaste any man might hereafter desire a rehersall : i shall reherse as many of theim as i can call to remembraunce , and they are cōmenly suche as here foloweth.the firste propriety chiefly belonging unto theim is , [ 35 ] to be excedingly ignoraunt , & without any maner { per}ceyuyng of all learninge to flee & eschewe matrimony or wedlocke , and in stede of it to kepe as many harlottes as they liste / to beare in their handes a shepehoke of silver bounde about with a towell , to weare a mitre with hornes / to go after the maner of pageaunt{is } in processiōs / to have their crowne brode shaven / to have many titles & townes & a very large dominion undre their sprincle , ( for i will use their owne tearme ) to leade aboute with a certay ne pompe goodly palfrayes , [ 36 ] and that a great many of them , afterthe maner of one triumphinge , to be proude with all maner pompe & gorgiousnes after i e courte facion / to kepe officialles / that is to say , certaine robbers & pillers of provinces , & tormentours of pore men / to kill soules by tiranny & excōicacyons / & ( whiche thinge i had almost forgotten ) to painte & set up in every place the armes of their kinned ramping lions , & suche other monumentes , with a shepehoke & a bisshops crosse put therunto to set forth their fingers to the shewe , decked with goodly ryng{is } of golde to arme their handes w t purple gloues , leste els they might be a colde in the middes of their ceremonies / to sprincle dombe stones & stockes in the churches , hauig a ladder set to every wal ) w t i wot not what war to cōfirme , 〈2 pages missing 〉 vnkynde , wicked / withoute affeccion / false accusers .

sentence1: for all this time the prestes hadde their wives , and the monkes were at their liberte , to goo or to come , excepte it were a certen of them whiche upon their owne braine , wholly addicted themselves to that rule , withoute either counsellpage xixor commaundemente of god , to make [ 118 ] sathan apere the aungell of lighte to the excecated worlde , as the sequele here declareth.i reade in the chronicle of cirillus the greke heremite , de processu sui ordinis ad abbatem ioachim , that aymericus a [ 119 ] frenche man , beinge the popes legate and patriarke of antioche , gathered togither by vertu of his commission , a certen nombre of dispersed heremites in the mounte of carmelus .
sentence2: [ 1061 ] sometimes , contrary hereunto , the divell will goe about to deceave them with higher imaginations , preferring unto them other orders of religion , which be more strait than that , wherein they are entered : & especially the holy order of the carthusiansthe which thing he doth , to allure them out of their religion with this pretence , that after he hath once entised them out of their religion , he may then take full possession of them , and carry them upon his hornes whither he listeth.some times also the divell bringeth them to be in love excedingly with solitary life , using thereunto the examples , & lives of the auncient holy heremites : to the end that when he hath led them from al company through this solitary walke , having them there alone , where they can not take advise or counsaile of their spiritvall fathers , and confessours , hee may the more easily prevaile against them.but among all these kindes of temptations , the most daungerous are those , [ 1062 ] that come under pretence of goodnes , and doe beare a shew of vertve .

sentence1: and now crafty flatterers which have once served for their wages in time and place of the sclender assalte , doo afterwardes requyre and perswade you for that seruyse to geue them the spoile of other holdes remaining continuallye in more daunger truly frenchmen and scottes be but feble ennemies , and at certaine times do sclenderly assalt castels , towers , and such maner of holdes : the devil seking like a ro ring lion , whom he may devoure , nighte & day , winter and sommer , with a wonderful forse of wicked spirites , doth ever besiege by shoprickes , shires , townes , and parishes.yf these places be not wel furnished with stout and trve soldiers of bothe the sortes ( i meane both officers in civile policy , and also prelates in ecclesiasticall ministery ) or if those souldiers be unprovided of necessary livings and dewe wages , then must the people nedes perishe and be destroyd for their owne sinnes , and the bloud of their bodies and soules requyred at your handes , whiche be charged and trusted of both god , and the king to provide souldiers to those places , and also wages and liuinges to maintaine those soldiers continually.how be it now many personages , benefices , offices , and fees be sold unto covetous bribers for money , which seke nothing but the vantage of extorcion , robbry and spoile , and fewe of them be freely given unto faithful ministers & officers for their woorthines , which could and would by diligent doinge of their duty , governe , instruct and cherishe goddes people , the kinges subiectes.and therefore nowe the most part of men lacking teachers & rulers , do without griefe of conscience , or feare of punishment , abuse every thinge unto the ruine and destruccion , whiche god hath ordained unto the upholding & increase of a christian commune welth.as for example , now bying and selling is not used as a provision for good cheape and great plenty , but made the most occasion of dearth and scarsity .

sentence2: but our trve defense shall be as a salve to this sore , and where they would fester with biting corrasies , we doubt not to cure with wholesome cordials , and against their vaine sclaunders to use the defensatiue of trve dealing , that all this roauing shooters darts shall be , i trust , but as bulrushes , and his endevour as of one that worketh against the streame , who while he laboureth to disgrace the gospell , shall gaine shame to himselfe : to whome that saiing of hierome may be returned , [ 490 ] frustra niti , neque aliud fatigando , nisi odium quaerere , extremae dementiae est , to strive in vaine , and to purchase hatred with wearines is extreame madnes.the sixt perswasion .

sentence1: there are but too many such as you be , that by sinister informations and sclaunders , goe about to hinder godly and holy attempts , fishing out some thing whereby to stay i t same , by all meanes they can : but god be praised such false and light reportes , such naughty dealings , have turned and doe commonly turne to the beginners shames , and to gods glory the more , and his peoples good and comfort , as in deede this did : for though this godly exercise were a time stayd , by misreportes , iet at length was it taken in hande , with the good countenance and liking of authority , whereof you and such might learne , to give over such rusty cankered practises , and to take a new and better course ; if y had any grace.it fareth now adays ( gentle reader ) in the building of gods spiritvall house and city , which is his church here upon earth even as it did in old time ( which conformity and likelihood may serve greatly to our instruction , admonition and comfort ) when at gods appointment , the house and temple of god , and the city ierusalem were to be reedified , god stirring up for that purpose king cirus , and darius , & preparing the heartes of other of his people to further and advaunce that worke , as we may see in the holy stories of ezra , and nehemiah , the thing 〈 ◊ 〉 well begun , was greatly hindred , somtime by colourable vndermining after a politik maner , & by false accusation , making cōplaint even to the king , somtime by conspiracy & open force & violence ; iet notwithstanding ( all preparatiōs and subtill devises cōming to naught ) the work , though with much a do , by gods meruellous providence ; went lustily & luckely forward , and was at i e last happily finished .
sentence2: but the great losses and dammages which in sundry sorts i have sustained , do not so much grieve my hart , as the rash , lewde , fond , and most vntrue fables and reports of me , and my studies philosophicall , have done , & iet do : which cōmonly , after their first hatching , and divelish devising , immediatly with great speede , are generally all the realme overspread ; and to some , seeme trve ; to other , they are doubtfull : and to only the wise , modest , discreet , godly , and charitable ( and chiefely to such as have some acquaintance with me ) they appeare , and are knowne to be fables , untruths , and utterly false reports , and sclaunders .

sentence2: yea they muste so behave them selves towardes such men , that both the personnes then selves and also other may understande that they be sore agrieued with their wicked actes , and sclaunders , wherewith they trouble the congregation of god.if any dy in excōmunication , let not the other mēbres of the congregation be present at his buriall , but let them compte him as a cast away , seinge that he died without the invocation of the name of christe , and acknowledging of his synnes.therfore the superentendant , the pastour and other deputed to this ministery , muste use excōmunication onely against open il livers , whiche wil not amende , and not in civile matters , as to require dettes , for of these thinges the politike iudgementes of the officers muste give sentence , and observe that way , whiche is described in our reformation set forth heretofore , cōcerning this matter and if neede shal require , it shall be iet more largely described by the advise of our counsell .

sentence2: let us pay frankly this debt : so shall we worke our owne safety , strengthen the common wealth , and serve god and our country in trueth.37 and thus we learne , that if the ministers earnestly pray [ 4 ] for , [ 231 ] and faithfully teache the prince , and the people ; if the prince and the people sincerely feare , and serve god ; feare him as an omnipotent lord , and iust iudge , and withall love him as a most loving father , serve him in cleansing , and feeding his church ; cleansing it from false doctrine , idolatry , superstition , and simony ; feeding it with the word , by causing it eueriewhere to be preached , which will be by providing maintenance for the preachers thereof , and compelling all subiects to heare gods word , and receive his sacraments : further if the prince carefully consider of the common wealth , to represse the evil , encourage and strengthen the good , and ouerlooke the whole ; and doe choose wise , religious , lovers of the trveth , and haters of covetousnesse under him to governe it : if in this great and stately counsell of the kingdome ( banishing private affections ) it sincerely be sought , by lawe to set foorth and preferre trve religion , and withall to bridle the desperate tongues of gainesayers : if by strength of good lawes they represse monstrous apparell , and excessive diet , deceitful bargaining , usury , adultery , unlawfully stolen contracts ; and so provide for the poore , that christ in his members may be relieved : if the officers of the common wealth keepe good lawes themselves ; and faithfully , without foolish pity ( which is crueltie ) see them executed upon others ; if the people like good subiectes feare god , honour the prince , live peaceably , and seeke the safety of their country : lastly , if we all linked together in love , liberally relieve the common wealth , and frankly supply the want therof , for our owne safety : then doubtlesse the lord wil blesse and preserve our prince , and us , and stablish this kingdome in peace , and prosperity , to flourish and to continve .

sentence1: this romish monster , i meane covetousnes , hath so inflamed and set a fire ( as i have said ) the hartes of men , that they do not refuse , [ 91 ] as s. paule saith , to sell them selves to i e devell , under sin ( for simony can be no lesse then perditiō , both to i e vyer & the seller ) so greatly be we given to lucre & to gaines , but what shall it profit a man to gaine all i e world if he loose his owne soule , saith christ , yea let christe say what he will , that is a thinge we regardenot we have him moch in our mouthes and cōmunication ( as it doth become us ) but in our life and conversation we do plainly declare i t in very dede we do nothing esteme him , for our lives doo nothinge agree with his worde or commaundementes : we call him father , and heavenly father , but we do not use oure selves towardes him as lovinge children , yea we call him i e lorde and the livinge lord , but we do nothinge lesse then shewe oure selves obediente servauntes unto him : god saithe by his prophette malachy .

sentence1: and therfore s. dionise calleth the breade , [ 340 ] holy breade , and the cuppe an holy cuppe , as soone as they bee sette uppon the aultate to the use of the holy communion.but specially they may be called holy and consecrated , when they be separated to that holy use of christes owne wordes , whiche he spake for that purpose , [ 341 ] saiing of the breade : this is my body , and of the wine : this is my bloude.so that commonly the authors , before those wordes be spoken , do take the breade and wine but as other common bread and wine , but after those woordes be pronounced over theim , than they take theim for consecrated and holy breade and wine.not that the bread and wine can be partakers of any holines or godlinesse , or can be the body and bloode of christ , but that they represent the very body and bloude of christe , and the holy foode and nourishement , which we have by him , and so they be called by the names of the body & bloud of christ , as the signe , token and figure is called by the name of the very thinge , whiche it sheweth and signifieth.and therefore as s. ambrose in the wordes before cited by the adversaries , saith , that beefore the consecration , it is bread , and after the cōsecration , it is christes body : so in other placeshe dothe more plainly sette forth his meaninge , saiing these wordes : [ 342 ] before the benediction of the heavenly wordes , it is called an other kinde of thinge , but after the consecration , is signified the body of christ .

sentence2: and well to be marked it is , that our histories doe witnesse , that all the people of france generally , were mervailously anguished & grieved with the prisonment & captivity which they saw their king suffer , but especially the people of the countrey of languedoc : for the estates of the said countrey ordained , that if the king were not delivered within a yeare , that every one , both men and women , should lay by all coloured garments , such also as were jagged and cut , and such as were enriched with gold , silver , or other strange and costly fashion : likewise , to make [ k ] cease all stage - plays , morrisdauncings , piping , yea and plays , pastimes and daunces ; in signe and token of their mourning and lamentation for their princes captivity .

sentence1: and therfore we shall pray him to lette passe over for this onis his longe chyldysshe ensample of his good child , which for all the nurture of his father and his mother , and all the wisedome that he lerned of them , and all his love to them and to their cōmaundementes , and all the trust in his fathers promises , for whiche he goth with [ b ] good will to scole / findinge iet by the way some companions that fall to play , is ra•ysshed of his remembraunce / and forgetyng father and mother , and all their promises , & all their kindenes , & all their lawes , & all the wisedomes that he lerned of them , and all the nurtur turtur that they taught him , standeth still and loketh on them / and after falleth to wurke with them at some suche prety plays of lykelyhed as children be wo nt to play , as chyrystone mary bone , bokyll pit , spurne point , cobnutte or quaytyng : let us leve i say this good childe at his game , till he be fette either home with his father , or to scole with his maister with thre stripes for his tarienge and trewauntynge by the way ( whiche is more mete for suche a childe , then after his lustes playd out , tindals tragicall processe of [ c ] remembraunce of his olde profession , with temptacions over his harte , and the lawe his right hange man , turmētynge of conscience , fere of destruccion and almoste desperate drede of hanging ) now let tindale therfore in stede of this child , take for ensample some of the trew members of his owne electe chirche , that hath the felinge faith of his owne false heresies / and not a litell childe , but a great slouen slouche , that out of his boys age is twenty winter stepte into his knauys age .

sentence1: and where as , they bee wholely given to so foule and detestable sensualytee , they dooe interprete it , to be , the commaundemente , of the heavenly father , persuadyng to women and honeste matrones , that it is impossible for them , to be partakerres of the kingdome of heaven excepte they doe abhominably prostitute , and make common theire owne bodies to all men , sithe that it is , written , that we muste forsake and renounce , to all thinges , i • we love best , and that we ought to suffer all kindes of infamy , or reproche , for christsake , beside that , that i e publicans , and harlottes shallbe preferred , to the ryghtwes , in the kingdome of heaven , there is no ende , nor measure of ther infidelity , and falshod , of their liing and sedition , with the which vices these disobedient persons are on every side infectid .
sentence2: for that ( as their embassadors then affirmed ) they had found by experience , since the time that the people of their citty had ceased to use secret confession of their sinnes , that all their common wealth abounded with such horrible vices against iustice , [ 36 ] and other vertves , as in former ages were utterly unknowne to their people.and as touching our owne country of england , i appeale not only to the grave iudgement , and testimony of all the iudges , iustices , and other magistrates , and officers , in every sheire : but even also unto the manifold , lamentable , and most grievous complaints , of the increase of late yeres of so much false deceitfull dealing , and other wickednes specified ( with rehearsall of many horrible particulars ) in divers acts of sundry late parliaments , enacted , and published in print , by full consent of all the estates of our realme , yea , and by the consent of all the new archbishops , and bishops , who openly agreed and gave their voices in those parliaments unto those so lamentable complaints , whether all sinnes of murder , incest , adultery , theft , wilfull periury , subornation of false witnesse , forging of false evidences , and writinges , liing , deceitfull dealing , fraudulent banckrupting , slaundering , gluttony , delicacy , drunkennes , ruffianly , and womanly apparell , and all kinde of pride , arrogancy , and presumption , have not much more increased in our realme , since the time that the use of secret cōfession of our sins to our ghostly father hath bin banished away from thence .

sentence1: we must fight , saith he with avarice , with vnchastitie , with anger , & ambition : we muste wrastle continually with carnall vices , and the temptacions of the worlde : for our soule , consideringe that it is seged with the whole army of the devill , is scarsly able to stande against such a violent assault .
sentence2: for as atlas is faigned to support the heavens with his shoulders , so must the world be held up by discipline , & those vices cut off with the sword of reformation , that fight against honesty ; for her valour and courage will soone weaken by impunity and evill example ; but as the cutting off the head of a serpent killeth the body , so the immoderate passions of i e mind rooted out in the beginning , the whole body of this hidious mōster voluptuousnes is destroyd , and the tranquility of the mind possest with greater ioy ; for being once taught to loath vice , & traded in wel doing , from the cradle , is thereby so well qualified , as it doth not easily chaunge any good course it vndertakes , but upon well grounded reasons .

sentence2: for if this were a trve position ; then a man might beleeve no history to be trve , which is not in the bible ; no maximes , or grounds of any sciences , nor common principles , left knowen unto us by the light of nature ( as that two and two make foure ) nor that there is any such countrey as america , & c. neither might a man ( with safe conscience ) doe infinite many things permitted by humane lawes , and sundry of them also commaunded to be done : because all these histories and principles , and the most of these lawes be such ; as can never ( by any sound reason ) be positiuely , immediately , and particularly prooved out of scripture : but onely by this generality , that therefore they may be beleeved , or done ; because they are not contrary to scripture , are agreeable to the vncorrupted light of nature , or to sundry credible mens experience , or are by the politique lawes of our countrey , receiued.for who can give any other sound reason directly drawen from the scripture ; that theft shall be punished with death : that matters of fact shall bee tried by a iury of twelve , led sometimes not by witnesses , but by circumstances and probable inducements : that the eldest sonne shall have all his fathers land ( by descent ) from the rest of his brethren , though they bee never so many ; who no lesse then the eldest are descending from him : that my kinsman remooved ( perhaps five or sixe degrees ) descending of the whole bloud from my fathers brother , shall , and lawfully may inherite my lande , before mine owne fathers sonne by another wife : that at one and twenty yeeres , a man may effectually sell his lande , but not the day before , albeit hee have received my money : that the wrecke of the sea , albeit the owner of the goods bee certainely knowen , shall bee confiscated , and belong to the prince : that a stray proclaimed ( according to lawe ) after a ieere and a day , shall belong to the lord of the mannour , where it was taken up : with infinite such like?therefore , it is no good , nor safe ground , that the innouatours doe stand upon : when as ( being pressed to take such oath according to the lawes of the realme ) they alleage ; that in conscience they may not doe it , because they finde no direct warrant for it by scripture , whereupon to stay their consciences .

sentence1: god hath put i • goods of this worlde into the ritche mens hands , [ 100 ] that they shuld distribute part of them to the pore people .
sentence2: therefore , as the perfection of the auncient men of the old testament was , not to forsweare themselves : so the perfection of christian men is not to sweare at all , because they are so cōmaunded of christ , whose commaundement must in no case be broke• : although that i e city of rome is contrary to this d••ctryne of christ even as in many things she is found contray to her selfe.as touching the taking away of temporal goods from those that are ecclesiastical persons offending habitualiter : [ 6600 ] by such as are temporall lordes , i will not affirme any thing to be lawful in this matter ( as in other matters before ) that is not agreable to charity : and that for because it is a hard matter for a man to take another mans goods from him without breaking of charity , because peradventure he that taketh away , is the more mooved to suche maner of taking away be reason of the desire he hath to those goods , which he indeuoureth to take away : or els , because of some displeasure or hatred to the person , from whom he goeth about to take away those goods , then that hee from whom those goodes be taken , should be amended .

sentence1: & c. the firste new god lucifer was of good conforte and courage upō the setting up of the temple & of the newe god , in comparison of whiche temple that sumptuous and gorgious temple of diana was in a maner nothinge , but he wolde also receive and beare awey the frutes & tribute of his labour ( for thempier of rome was plucked up by the rotes , & clene destroyd , the city of rome was become i e popes seate / whiche reioysedde greatly , & was proude in spirite , that he was comen into the place of so great an emperour ) he toke againe astulphe king of lumbardy , which did warre against the pope , and did sore vexe him for that he did so by litle & litle take away of the lordships lienge nere unto the city of rome with the iniury of the pope.wherfore stephen the pope did desire pipine of aide and helpe , and i t he wold defende his goods and the province from the kinge astulphe , so pipine did on his harneis , & went to rome with the pope , ( whiche was comen his owne selfe unto him for succour ) & did drive out astulphe from rome .

sentence2: for if this were a trve position ; then a man might beleeve no history to be trve , which is not in the bible ; no maximes , or grounds of any sciences , nor common principles , left knowen unto us by the light of nature ( as that two and two make foure ) nor that there is any such countrey as america , & c. neither might a man ( with safe conscience ) doe infinite many things permitted by humane lawes , and sundry of them also commaunded to be done : because all these histories and principles , and the most of these lawes be such ; as can never ( by any sound reason ) be positiuely , immediately , and particularly prooved out of scripture : but onely by this generality , that therefore they may be beleeved , or done ; because they are not contrary to scripture , are agreeable to the vncorrupted light of nature , or to sundry credible mens experience , or are by the politique lawes of our countrey , receiued.for who can give any other sound reason directly drawen from the scripture ; that theft shall be punished with death : that matters of fact shall bee tried by a iury of twelve , led sometimes not by witnesses , but by circumstances and probable inducements : that the eldest sonne shall have all his fathers land ( by descent ) from the rest of his brethren , though they bee never so many ; who no lesse then the eldest are descending from him : that my kinsman remooved ( perhaps five or sixe degrees ) descending of the whole bloud from my fathers brother , shall , and lawfully may inherite my lande , before mine owne fathers sonne by another wife : that at one and twenty yeeres , a man may effectually sell his lande , but not the day before , albeit hee have received my money : that the wrecke of the sea , albeit the owner of the goods bee certainely knowen , shall bee confiscated , and belong to the prince : that a stray proclaimed ( according to lawe ) after a ieere and a day , shall belong to the lord of the mannour , where it was taken up : with infinite such like?therefore , it is no good , nor safe ground , that the innouatours doe stand upon : when as ( being pressed to take such oath according to the lawes of the realme ) they alleage ; that in conscience they may not doe it , because they finde no direct warrant for it by scripture , whereupon to stay their consciences .

sentence2: i doubt not [ d ] but that machiavell thus though : for wee see it by the practise of the machiavellists , which never shot at other marke , than to ruinate in france all the nobility , the better to establish their tiranny , at ease without contradiction : and for this effect have they cassed , violated , and overthrowne all the good lawes of the kingdome , by the meanes of which it hath always hitherto been maintained : and machiavell confesseth and said trve , which his disciples having well marked , and desiring to ruinate the said kingdome , have not failed to beginne by the lawes thereof , knowing well [ 565 ] that having ruinated her foundations , she will be easily dissolved and overthrowne.but to confute this maxime , i will alledge no other thing but that wee see in our french histories , that our kingdome was as much or more flourishing , and better [ e ] governed before there were any parliaments in france , than since : for the parliament of paris ( which is the ancientest ) was established and constituted in the time of king philip le bel , anno 1294 . that of tholouse , during the raigne of charles the seventh , anno 1444 . that of bourdeaux , in the time of the same king , anno 1451 . that of daulphin , in the time also of the same king ( but by the authority of king lewis the eleventh his sonne then daulphin , and then inhabiting in dauphine ) in anno 1453 . the parliaments of dijon and of provence , in the time of the said king [ f ] lewis the eleventh .

sentence1: let us than god ly recompense these thinges with our selves & let us confirme , and ster up our faith in him lette us celebrate the remembraunce of him worthely , let us most studoyusly in al oure wordes , and dedes exalte his death , resurreccion , heavenly glory , and kingdome , let us reioise in our owne behalfe that this sonne of god died for our sinnes , rosse againe forour instificacion , ascended into heaven , and reigneth at the right hand of the father , furthermorelette us couragiously every one of us take up our crosse , and valiantly folowe this our capitaine , and love one another according to his cōmaundement , as he loved vs. for al we are one bread , & one body , because we be parttakers of one breade and one cup.after this prayr , there shall a prayr be made for al the necessites of the congregaciō and cheifely for those men , which shall communicate the nexte day.and whan the people have ended their secrete prayr , the minister shal cōclude the preparacion with this collecte.almightie everlastinge god , heauealye father , because we can please the only in thy deare sonne , sanctify our bodies , and soules , and graunte us , that to morowe we may receive the holesome communion of him , in his holy supper with a godly , and faithfull desier , and all thanckefulnes , that beinge confirmed againe conceruynge thy perpetual mercy , and love towardes us , and ever goinge forwarde in a new life , we may live unto the and serve the thorough our lorde iesus christ with more feare , and study , to the praise of thy name , and profite of thy people .

sentence1: wherunto this commaundement ministreth unto us an instruction in christe.in the seventh cōmaundement , thou shalt not committe auoutrie , the people shall be taughte , that god forbiddeth , and damneth all copulations beside matrimony , whiche he him selfe ordeined , and moreuer al lust , and inordinate motions , all intemperaunce , al delites and pleasures vnseamely for christian men , al riote and vncomelines in meates , drinkes , garmentes , gesture , wordes , and dedes , of whiche any cause of vnchastnes may rise , or of any perturbation , wherby the body shall be made vnpliable , rebellious and stubburne towarde the service of the spirite.secondly that god warneth and accuseth us in this commaundement of our natural lechery , filthy , and immoderate conrupiscēce in al thinges , whiche he him selfe gave to susteine , and cherishe our bodies.thyrdly that thorow the knowledge of this disease we are driven to repentaunce of the same , and to seeke the grace , and mercy of christe , whiche turneth away the fathers wrath deserved thorowe this evill , and whiche quencheth the remnauntes of this disease remaininge in the fleshe , and worketh in us trve cōtinency , chastity , and perfecte holines in all thinges , that beinge healped with the assistence of the holy gost we may resiste evil concupiscences , and al intemperaunce , cleansinge oure selves from all filth of the fleshe , and of the spirite , and workinge holines with the feare of god .

sentence1: the crueltie , violence , and rapin of souldiers is so great , that there is no difference in them from the fury of barbarians , beeing conquerers of their enemies , there is nothing else but fire and blood , that have entered into divers places of this realme , but to beate , binde , ransome , imprison , sacke , violated women and maides , to pull iong children from their mothers breasts , spoile , breake , rent , and throw the goods of poore people under the horse feete , and to beare away the rest , to leave the wife and children in great misery without bread , [ 1306 ] following after their husbands and fathers : and horses led away by them , is an ordinary thing among souldiers : these evills happen partly for want of pollicy and commandement , and partly for want of pay and good order , and distribution of the treasures of this land .

sentence2: but to the purpose againe of the story.iohn hus seeing so many faire promises , [ 7850 ] and the assurance which the emperour had geven unto him , sent answere unto the emperour that he would come unto the councell : but before hee departed out of the realme of boheme , and specially out of the towne of prage , he did write certaine billes long inough afore , as well in latine as in the bohemian language , and almaine , and caused them to be set and fastened upon the gates of the cathedrall churches and parish churches , cloisters and abbayes , signifieng unto them all , that he would go to the generall councell at constance , wherof if any man have any suspition of his doctrine , that he should declare it before the lord conrade , or bishop of prage , or if he had rather , at the generall councell , for there he would render and give up unto every one , and before them all , an accompt and reason of his faith .
